resource.source:
<objectXMLWrap>
               <mods xmlns="http://www.loc.gov/mods/v3">
                  <recordInfo>
                     <recordOrigin>WorldCat:644162326</recordOrigin>
                     <recordContentSource>ISIL:OCLC-EXW</recordContentSource>
                  </recordInfo>
                  <titleInfo>
                     <title>Earl Weygandt collection, 1918-1919.</title>
                  </titleInfo>
                  <abstract>Letters written by Earl Weygandt to his girl friend, Florence Shafer in Warren, Ohio. Weygandt was a clarinet player in the U.S. Army Band during World War I. The correspondence began in August, 1918 when Earl was in the United States waiting to be deployed, and follows his travels to military bases in France. He describes the cities he is in and his accommodations. </abstract>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Western Michigan University</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/rps">Repository</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
               </mods>
            </objectXMLWrap>
resource.title: Earl Weygandt collection, 1918-1919.
resource.abstract: Letters written by Earl Weygandt to his girl friend, Florence Shafer in Warren, Ohio. Weygandt was a clarinet player in the U.S. Army Band during World War I. The correspondence began in August, 1918 when Earl was in the United States waiting to be deployed, and follows his travels to military bases in France. He describes the cities he is in and his accommodations.

resource.source:
<objectXMLWrap>
               <mods xmlns="http://www.loc.gov/mods/v3">
                  <recordInfo>
                     <recordOrigin>WorldCat:163580484</recordOrigin>
                     <recordContentSource>ISIL:OCLC-WQ064</recordContentSource>
                  </recordInfo>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Clauder, Joseph W., 1910-1990.</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/cre">Creator</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
                  <titleInfo>
                     <title>Papers and photographs, 1912-1990.</title>
                  </titleInfo>
                  <abstract>Papers of the Milwaukee, Wis. native related to his World War II service as the bandmaster for the 128th Infantry Band, 32nd Division. The bulk of the collection are photocopied letters received by Clauder thanking him and the 32nd Division band for concerts performed at various Army gatherings in the United States, Australia, and New Guinea. There are also letters commending the band for volunteering to fly rations to soldiers fighting at Buna. A folder of newspaper clippings provides information about the 32nd Division in New Guinea, the band, and Clauder's return to civilian life. Also included are several photographs of the band marching in parades, performing in New Guinea, band veterans playing at reunions, and a 1941 photograph of the band at Camp Beauregard (Louisiana). There is an individual photograph of Clauder, in uniform, standing with a "Red Arrow" drum in New Guinea. Two identified 1912 photographs show "Clauder's Band" lead by Joesph and William Clauder (most likely Joseph W. Clauder's grandfather and father). </abstract>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Wisconsin Veterans Museum Research Center</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/rps">Repository</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
               </mods>
            </objectXMLWrap>
resource.title: Papers and photographs, 1912-1990.
resource.abstract: Papers of the Milwaukee, Wis. native related to his World War II service as the bandmaster for the 128th Infantry Band, 32nd Division. The bulk of the collection are photocopied letters received by Clauder thanking him and the 32nd Division band for concerts performed at various Army gatherings in the United States, Australia, and New Guinea. There are also letters commending the band for volunteering to fly rations to soldiers fighting at Buna. A folder of newspaper clippings provides information about the 32nd Division in New Guinea, the band, and Clauder's return to civilian life. Also included are several photographs of the band marching in parades, performing in New Guinea, band veterans playing at reunions, and a 1941 photograph of the band at Camp Beauregard (Louisiana). There is an individual photograph of Clauder, in uniform, standing with a "Red Arrow" drum in New Guinea. Two identified 1912 photographs show "Clauder's Band" lead by Joesph and William Clauder (most likely Joseph W. Clauder's grandfather and father).
resource.extent: Papers : 0.1 linear ft. (2 folders) and.Photographs : (6 folders and 2 oversized folders)Paper prints : (1 folder)
resource.displayEntry: Clauder, Joseph W., 1910-1990. Papers and photographs, 1912-1990.

resourceRelations.content: Clauder, Joseph W., 1910-1990. Papers and photographs, 1912-1990.

resource.source:
<objectXMLWrap>
               <mods xmlns="http://www.loc.gov/mods/v3">
                  <recordInfo>
                     <recordOrigin>WorldCat:50822128</recordOrigin>
                     <recordContentSource>ISIL:OCLC-MHR</recordContentSource>
                  </recordInfo>
                  <titleInfo>
                     <title>Army bands miscellaneous photograph collection. 1884-</title>
                  </titleInfo>
                  <abstract>Contains the following type of materials: photographs. Covers the following time period: 1884- Contains photographs of the following military units and organizations: Army Band at various periods; the Old Guard Fife & Drum Corps; United States (U.S.) Continental Army Band; United States Marine Corps (USMC) Pipe & Drums; Women's Army Corps (WAC) Band; 2nd Marine Division Drum & Bugle Corps; 5th U.S. Army Band; 81st U.S. Army Band; 3rd Brigade Band; National Guard (NG) of Pennsylvania; West Point Band. General description of the collection: The Army bands miscellaneous photograph collection consists of photographs of musical units and musicians from the Indian Wars through the 20th century, mostly of the U.S. Army, but with a smattering of USMC and United States Navy (USN) musical units as well. Photos show those musical units on parade and in concert with individual directors, leaders, drum majors, and personnel. There are photos of the Army Band Library and several showing the Army Band uniforms from 1924-1965. There are jazz ensembles, Army and Navy choral groups and the School of Music at Norfolk, Virginia. There are Drum and Bugle Corps as well as the Old Guard Fife and Drum Corps. Many of the photos are in color. </abstract>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>US Army, Mil Hist Institute</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/rps">Repository</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
               </mods>
            </objectXMLWrap>
resource.title: Army bands miscellaneous photograph collection. 1884-
resource.abstract: Contains the following type of materials: photographs. Covers the following time period: 1884- Contains photographs of the following military units and organizations: Army Band at various periods; the Old Guard Fife & Drum Corps; United States (U.S.) Continental Army Band; United States Marine Corps (USMC) Pipe & Drums; Women's Army Corps (WAC) Band; 2nd Marine Division Drum & Bugle Corps; 5th U.S. Army Band; 81st U.S. Army Band; 3rd Brigade Band; National Guard (NG) of Pennsylvania; West Point Band. General description of the collection: The Army bands miscellaneous photograph collection consists of photographs of musical units and musicians from the Indian Wars through the 20th century, mostly of the U.S. Army, but with a smattering of USMC and United States Navy (USN) musical units as well. Photos show those musical units on parade and in concert with individual directors, leaders, drum majors, and personnel. There are photos of the Army Band Library and several showing the Army Band uniforms from 1924-1965. There are jazz ensembles, Army and Navy choral groups and the School of Music at Norfolk, Virginia. There are Drum and Bugle Corps as well as the Old Guard Fife and Drum Corps. Many of the photos are in color.

resource.source:
<objectXMLWrap>
               <mods xmlns="http://www.loc.gov/mods/v3">
                  <recordInfo>
                     <recordOrigin>WorldCat:49223447</recordOrigin>
                     <recordContentSource>ISIL:OCLC-MHR</recordContentSource>
                  </recordInfo>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Reimer, Dennis J. (Dennis Joe), 1939-</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/cre">Creator</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
                  <titleInfo>
                     <title>Dennis J. Reimer photograph collection. 1995-1999.</title>
                  </titleInfo>
                  <abstract>Contains the following type of materials: photographs. Covers the following time period: 1995-1999. Contains photographs of the following military units and organizations: Chief of Staff of the Army; the Old Guard, 3rd U.S. Infantry Regiment; U.S. Army Band and Chorus; 82nd Airborne Division; 101st Airborne Division. General description of the collection: The Dennis J. Reimer photograph collection consists of photographs for the years General Reimer served as Chief of Staff of the Army, 1995-1999. All photos are color prints. There are photos of visiting dignitaries from abroad, many being his equivalent in rank and position from other countries' armies. There are photos of reviews and ceremonies, many showing the U.S. Army Band and the Old Guard - 3rd U.S. Infantry Honor Guard Battalion and ceremonial units. There are photos of social events both at the Reimer's quarters #1 as well as at the Pentagon and elsewhere. Also photos of General Reimer's visits abroad and the state ceremonies in those countries. There are numerous photos of General Reimer visiting U.S. troops at stateside training areas and military posts, as well as, his visit to U.S. troops abroad, ie., Germany, Bosnia, etc. There are photos of Reimer's participation at Army vs. Navy football games and ten-mile run competitions, several in which he personally participated. There are numerous occasions of promotion ceremonies, award presentations and retirement ceremonies and parades for U.S. Army personnel, and there are numerous photos of the activities of the Joint Chiefs of Staff on which board General Reimer served. </abstract>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>US Army, Mil Hist Institute</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/rps">Repository</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
               </mods>
            </objectXMLWrap>
resource.title: Dennis J. Reimer photograph collection. 1995-1999.
resource.abstract: Contains the following type of materials: photographs. Covers the following time period: 1995-1999. Contains photographs of the following military units and organizations: Chief of Staff of the Army; the Old Guard, 3rd U.S. Infantry Regiment; U.S. Army Band and Chorus; 82nd Airborne Division; 101st Airborne Division. General description of the collection: The Dennis J. Reimer photograph collection consists of photographs for the years General Reimer served as Chief of Staff of the Army, 1995-1999. All photos are color prints. There are photos of visiting dignitaries from abroad, many being his equivalent in rank and position from other countries' armies. There are photos of reviews and ceremonies, many showing the U.S. Army Band and the Old Guard - 3rd U.S. Infantry Honor Guard Battalion and ceremonial units. There are photos of social events both at the Reimer's quarters #1 as well as at the Pentagon and elsewhere. Also photos of General Reimer's visits abroad and the state ceremonies in those countries. There are numerous photos of General Reimer visiting U.S. troops at stateside training areas and military posts, as well as, his visit to U.S. troops abroad, ie., Germany, Bosnia, etc. There are photos of Reimer's participation at Army vs. Navy football games and ten-mile run competitions, several in which he personally participated. There are numerous occasions of promotion ceremonies, award presentations and retirement ceremonies and parades for U.S. Army personnel, and there are numerous photos of the activities of the Joint Chiefs of Staff on which board General Reimer served.
resource.displayEntry: Reimer, Dennis J. (Dennis Joe), 1939-. Dennis J. Reimer photograph collection.
